children.name: modest
children.definition: /ˈmɒdɪst, ˈmɒdəstǁˈmɑː-/  unwilling to talk about your abilities or achievements and to say that you are good at something, even when you are:
examples: khiêm tốn, nhún nhường
▪ Luke was too modest to talk about his past achievements.
▪ She was a shy, modest person, never one to push herself forward.
modestly[adverb]
thùy mị, đơn giản, e lệ
▪ ‘I couldn’t have done it without your help,’ Alec replied modestly.

children.name: self-effacing
children.definition: /ˌself ɪˈfeɪsɪŋ/  formal not wanting to talk about yourself or to attract attention:

children.name: khiêm tốn, không tìm cách gây ấn tượng với mọi người
examples: ▪ Her husband was a quiet, self-effacing man who spent much of his time in his study.
▪ In those days women were expected to be quiet, passive and self-effacing.

children.name: unassuming
children.definition: /ˌʌnəˈsjuːmɪŋ◂, -ˈsuː-ǁ-ˈsuː-/  not wanting to be noticed and not expecting to be treated in a special way, because you do not think you are important:

children.name: không tự phụ, khiêm tốn
examples: ▪ I often see her in the library. She’s such a nice, unassuming person.
▪ By now Chapman was famous, but on a social level he remained as unassuming as ever.

children.name: humble
children.definition: /ˈhʌmbəl/  thinking that you are unimportant and not as good or clever as other people, and therefore not expecting to be treated in a special way:
examples: khiêm tốn, nhún nhường
▪ Their father was a genuinely humble man, who had worked hard for his family all his life.
▪ Stephanie was humble enough to admit that others could probably do the job better than she could.
humbly[adverb]
nhún nhường, khiêm nhường
▪ ‘What do you think I should do?’ Lydia asked humbly.

children.name: unpretentious
children.definition: /ˌʌnprɪˈtenʃəs◂/  not trying to seem better than other people, even if you are rich, famous, clever etc:

children.name: không khoe khoang, không phô trương, khiêm tốn
examples: ▪ Umbria is a wonderful region, where life is simple and the people are unpretentious country folk.
▪ Jilly was surprised by how pleasant and unpretentious he was. Not like a big star at all.

children.name: put/run yourself down
children.definition: /ˌpʊt, ˌrʌn jɔːʳself ˈdaʊn/  to tell people that you are less good, skilful etc than you really are:

children.name: đặt bản thân thấp xuống/tự trách bản thân mình
examples: ▪ He puts himself down, but he’s really very gifted.
▪ You know you’re a good teacher. Don’t run yourself down all the time.

children.name: sell yourself short
children.definition: /ˌsel jɔːʳself ˈʃɔːʳt/  informal to not tell people enough about your skills, ability etc, especially in a situation where other people are deciding whether to offer you a job or choose you for something:

children.name: đánh giá thấp bản thân của mình
examples: ▪ If you sell yourself short at the interview, you’ll never get the job. Let them know how good you are.
▪ You’re brilliant at tennis - don’t sell yourself short.

children.name: underestimate yourself
children.definition: /ˌʌndərˈestɪmeɪt jɔːʳself, ˌʌndərˈestəmeɪt jɔːʳself/  to believe that you are less clever, good, skilful etc than you really are:

children.name: đánh giá thấp bản thân
examples: ▪ Don’t underestimate yourself -- you can easily win.
▪ I think you underestimate yourself when you say you couldn’t cope with a job like this.

children.name: modesty
children.definition: /ˈmɒdɪsti, ˈmɒdəstiǁˈmɑː-/  a modest way of behaving or talking:
examples: tính khiêm tốn, sự nhã nhặn
▪ His honesty and modesty endeared him to many people who valued his wise advice.
▪ ‘I’m a bank manager,’ she said, then added with typical modesty, ‘of a very small bank.’
false modesty
sự khiêm tốn giả tạo
when somebody only pretends to be modest
▪ Miranda was not one for false modesty. She enjoyed being told that she was beautiful.

children.name: humility
children.definition: /hjuːˈmɪlɪti, hjuːˈmɪləti/  when someone is not proud, and does not think that they are more important, clever etc than other people:

children.name: nhún nhường, sự khiêm tốn
examples: ▪ As I listened to him speak, I was filled with a sense of humility.
▪ Mother Theresa remained a woman of great humility, despite all the attention and praise her work received.

children.name: shyness
children.definition: /ˈʃaɪnɪs, ˈʃaɪnəs/ sự rụt rè, nhút nhát
examples: ▪ A course in assertiveness could help her overcome her shyness.
Một khóa học về sự quyết đoán có thể giúp cô vượt qua sự nhút nhát của mình.
▪ Greg wanted to ask Julie for a date, but shyness always held him back.
▪ Greg muốn mời Julie hẹn hò, nhưng sự rụt rẹ luôn khiến anh thất bại.

children.name: inhibition
children.definition: /ˌɪnhɪˈbɪʃən/  an uncomfortable feeling of shyness that makes it difficult for you to behave naturally, show your feelings, or do things that may be embarrassing:sự e ngại
examples: ▪ I was amazed at Sam’s lack of inhibition about singing in public.
Tôi rất ngạc nhiên trước sự không hề e ngại của Sam khi hát ở nơi công cộng.
lose your inhibitionsstop having inhibitions
mất hết e ngại
▪ Alcohol can make you lose all your inhibitions - but you may regret this the next morning!
Rượu có thể làm bạn quên mất hết mọi sự e ngại - nhưng bạn có thể hối tiếc vào sáng hôm sau!

children.name: come out of your shell
children.definition: /kʌm ˌaʊt əv jɔːʳ ˈʃel/  to become less shy and more willing to talk to people, especially as the result of an experience that has made you more confident:thoát khỏi vỏ bọc

children.name: ▪ When he first joined the company he was very quiet but now he’s come out of his shell a lot
examples: Khi lần đầu tiên gia nhập công ty anh ấy đã rất yên lặng nhưng bây giờ anh ấy đã thoát khỏi vỏ bọc của mình.
▪ Her manner is a little diffident, but she’ll soon come out of her shell with a little encouragement.
Phong cách của cô ấy có chút rụt rè, nhưng với sự khích lệ cô ấy sẽ sớm thoát khỏi võ bọc của mình.

children.name: bring sb out of their shell
children.definition: bring somebody out of their shell/ˌbrɪŋ somebody aʊt əv ðeəʳ ˈʃel/  to make someone less shy and more willing to talk to other people:mang ai ra khỏi vỏ bọc
examples: ▪ Emma was always such a shy girl, but these drama classes have really brought her out of her shell.
Emma luôn là một cô gái nhút nhát, nhưng những lớp học kịch nghệ này đã đưa cô ấy ra khỏi vỏ bọc của mình.
▪ If Nick stayed with you this vacation, perhaps it would bring him out of his shell a little.
Nếu Nick ở lại với bạn trong kỳ nghỉ này, có lẽ nó sẽ giúp anh ta thoát khỏi vỏ bọc của mình một chút.

children.name: open up
children.definition: /ˌəʊpən ˈʌp/  to gradually stop being shy, and become more willing to talk about yourself :
examples: dần cởi mở
▪ On our third date Melissa began to open up and told me about her family and about the years she spent in Italy.
Vào ngày thứ ba của chúng tôi, Melissa dần cởi mở hơn và nói với tôi về gia đình của cô ấy và những năm cô ấy ở Ý.
open up to
cởi mở với
▪ Many people find it easier to open up to a trained professional, such as a counsellor.
Nhiều người thấy dễ dàng cởi mở hơn với một chuyên gia được đào tạo như là một cố vấn.
open upphrasal verb cởi mở
to start to talk more about yourself and your feelings
_I've never opened uptoanyone like I do to you.

children.name: not confident about talking to people
shy
children.definition: /ʃaɪ/  not confident about talking to people, especially people you do not know:Nhút nhát
examples: ▪ David was always rather quiet and shy at school.
David thường khá trầm tính và nhút nhát ở trường.
▪ Carrie looked up at him and gave him a shy smile.
Carrie nhìn anh và mỉm cười với anh một cách e thẹn.
painfully shyextremely shy
cực nhút nhát
▪ He was painfully shy in public, but completely different at home with his family.
Anh ấy cực nhút nhát ở bên ngoài, nhưng hoàn toàn khác biệt ở nhà với gia đình anh ấy.
too shy to do something
quá nhút nhát để
▪ I was too shy to ask her out on a date.
Tôi đã quá nhút nhát không dám hỏi xin cô ấy hẹn hò.
go all shyspoken suddenly become very shy
trở nên vô cùng ngại ngùng
▪ Look, she’s gone all shy - stop teasing her.
Nhìn kìa, cô ấy ngại quá kìa - đừng chọc cô ấy nữa.
shy with girls/boys/adults etcshy when you are talking to girls, boys etc
Nhát gái / trai / người lớn vv
▪ Because little Danny spent all his time with his mother, he was rather shy with men.
Bởi vì cậu bé Danny toàn ở bên mẹ, cậu khá nhút nhát với con trai.
shyly[adverb]ngượng ngùng
▪ She looked shyly away when he said anything nice about her.
Cô ấy trông ngượng ngùng khi nói bất cứ điều gì về cô ấy.

children.name: timid
children.definition: /ˈtɪmɪd, ˈtɪməd/  frightened to talk to people or to give your opinion, because you have very little confidence:Nhút nhát
examples: ▪ Ralph’s wife was a small, timid woman who hardly ever spoke.
Vợ của Ralph là một người phụ nữ nhỏ bé, nhút nhát mà hầu như không bao giờ nói.
▪ ‘May I come in?’ said a timid little voice.
'Tôi có thể vào được không?', Một giọng nói nhút nhát cất lên.

children.name: bashful
children.definition: /ˈbæʃfəl/  someone who is bashful is unwilling to give their opinions or do something that they would enjoy, especially because they are embarrassed or afraid that they will look stupid:rụt rè, bẽn lẽn
examples: ▪ Don’t be bashful about telling your family how you feel.
Đừng rụt rè nói với gia đình bạn cảm nhận như thế nào.
▪ Kirsty gave Willy a bashful grin.
Kirsty mỉm cười bẽn lẽn với Willy.

children.name: coy
children.definition: /kɔɪ/  someone who is coy deliberately behaves in a shy way because they think it is attractive:e lệ, duyên dáng
examples: ▪ Teresa blushed when she saw me and turned very coy.
Teresa đỏ mặt khi nhìn thấy tôi và trở nên e lệ.
▪ Her mother encouraged her to use her feminine charm, to be coy and alluring.
Mẹ cô khuyến khích cô sử dụng sự quyến rũ nữ tính, duyên dáng và quyến rũ của mình.

children.name: diffident
children.definition: /ˈdɪfɪdənt, ˈdɪfədənt/  formal someone who is diffident does not like talking about their achievements or is not confident of their abilities:rụt rè
examples: ▪ Shaun became noticeably diffident when the conversation turned to the subject of his promotion.
Shaun trở nên cực kỳ rụt rè khi cuộc đối thoại quay sang đề tài quảng bá của anh.
diffident about
thiếu tự tin về
▪ Joe was humble and diffident about his own success.
Joe đã khiêm tốn và thiếu tự tin về thành công của mình.
diffidently[adverb] 1 cách rụt rè
▪ ‘I couldn’t possibly do an article for your magazine,’ said Irene diffidently, ‘I don’t write any more.’
"Tôi không thể làm một bài viết cho tạp chí của bạn," Irene nói một cách rụt rè, "Tôi không viết thêm nữa."

children.name: not wanting to be too friendly or to show your feelings
reserved
children.definition: /rɪˈzɜːʳvd/  someone who is reserved tries not to show their feelings to other people and does not talk a lot:kín đáo, nhút nhát
examples: ▪ English people have a reputation for being very reserved.
Người Anh có tiếng là rất kín đáo.
▪ That shy reserved young man had turned into a confident adult.
Chàng trai trẻ tuổi nhút nhát này đã biến thành một người đàn ông đầy tự tin.

children.name: withdrawn
children.definition: /wɪðˈdrɔːn, wɪθ-/  not wanting to talk to anyone, especially because you are upset or unhappy:lãnh đạm, thiếu chan hòa
examples: ▪ Mike was silent and withdrawn that evening.
Mike im lặng và lãnh đạm vào buổi tối hôm đó.
▪ After her husband died Priscilla became very withdrawn and seldom left her home.
Sau khi chồng cô qua đời, Priscilla trở nên rất lãnh đạm và hiếm khi ra khỏi nhà.
▪ He’d always been an unhappy, withdrawn little boy.
Anh ta luôn là một cậu bé thiếu chan hòa và không vui vẻ.

children.name: introverted
children.definition: /ˈɪntrəvɜːʳtɪd, ˈɪntrəvɜːʳtəd/  someone who is introverted thinks too much about their own interests or problems and it is difficult for them to talk to people:hướng nội, nội tâm
examples: ▪ Peters is just too introverted to be a good manager.
Peters chỉ là quá hướng nội nên khó làm người quản lý tốt.
▪ The young girl, once so lively, became introverted and developed a nervous stammer.
Cô gái trẻ, từng rất năng động, trở nên sống nội tâm và hay nói lấp 1 cách lo lắng.

children.name: inhibited
children.definition: /ɪnˈhɪbɪtəd, ɪnˈhɪbətəd/  shy and unwilling to express your feelings, especially feelings concerned with sex or with your own body:gượng gạo, gây ức chế
examples: ▪ I am far too inhibited to have rows with people.
Tôi quá gượng gạo để hòa vào với mọi người.
▪ He accused her of being snobbish and emotionally inhibited.
Ông cáo buộc bà là đua đòi và gây ức chế tình cảm.
inhibited about
rụt rè về
▪ Young people of the nineteenth century were, in general, extremely inhibited about sex.
Những người trẻ tuổi của thế kỷ XIX nhìn chung rất rụt rè về vấn đề tình dục giới tính.
